I just set up a custom layout for a particular page, and once again had to consult documentation and jump around between half a dozen pages before I figured out what I had gotten wrong. (This after I accidentally put new blocks on my entire site because I didn't realize I was editing the default page.)

There are a couple places where things can happen automagically in Backdrop, and this strikes me that it should be one of them. How about a contextual menu on a page, or a new tab on the Layout editor, that says "Enable custom layout for this page/the referring page". That should clone the existing layout, set it to only work on the existing path, maybe name it [Referring Page Title] Layout, and drop me back into the Layout editor.

Even better: when I go to the Layout editor from a particular screen, why not put a drop menu next to the Layout title so I can switch layouts on the fly? Put "add new..." on the bottom and life is easy.

I'll add, FWIW, that every time I have to do this, I completely forget that I want the Path field to be node/% and that the specific path is a Visibility condition.
I frequently forget to check back here, so if you need me to clarify, make sure I'm notified here.

I don't think it's quite ready for prime-time, but I believe @docwilmot has a start to this "per page layout" idea with the 2.x branch of the Layout nodes module. https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/layout_nodes

backdrop-contrib/layout_nodes

Alex Finnarn also created something similar, but coming at it from a different angle: https://github.com/alexfinnarn/node_layout

Besides, I’m not a dev. My intent with a feature request is to say “I want this,” then let y’all figure it out. Most of the time they go ignored in most other software, so I’m not expecting you to drop everything for me. It’s just nice to have it noted.

@Jeff Porten - This is all fine and you are welcome to submit ideas and request without going into Github. However, you should also feel free to comment on issues in Github without having to fully understand the issue. If you see an issue about a topic that interests you, feel free to post your support for the idea and or provide information about your use case.

Whether or not you have read the entire issue (or understand it), adding thoughts and context is helpful and helps move an issue along. Yes, Github can be intimidating. But, the more voices and opinions that we get in Github issues, the more information we have to make decisions.

NOTE: I used to feel the same way that you did and it took me a while to get over it. So I understand.

I got started by saying things like - "I might not understand this issue, but this is what I need/think? Here is my opinion (for what it's worth)."
Having said all this though, would it be reasonable to say that the only "good" explanation for layouts is the Backdrop docs?
Maybe they need some more breaking down and re-explaining

@klonos There's a basic issue here that you're presuming that all Backdrop users are also Backdrop volunteers. And in fact, it's fine to have a culture that promotes that—it's why I showed up for the Documentation talk, because I see how much work you're all doing and want to do my bit.

But at the moment I'm in Zulip or reading docs, I'm here to solve a problem, and that problem is top of mind. Asking me to switch gears and become a Backdrop volunteer at that moment is the worst possible time. And when the answer to a feature request is, "if you familiarize yourself with the five years of discussions we've had on this topic, you can usefully contribute," that's factually correct, but it's not helpful.

Sorry if this sounds churlish—it's not meant to be. I really wish I had the time to learn the style here, and be less intimidated by GitHub threads, but these are the facts on the ground.

I haven’t used field blocks at all, so I would never see that alert. What I wanted was a page with a couple View blocks on it, and what I briefly got was an entire website with a couple View blocks on it.

The easiest way to handle that is visibility restrictions (in the block under conditions) on the views blocks, so that they only show up on the pages you want them to. Have a separate layout for that page just to show a block would make things more complicated, not less.

You may want to create several templates - see if there are any commonalities in structure for the pages that have special blocks. I normally have at least 2 templates, one for the home page and one for the rest of the pages. If you just have special blocks and they're all in the same area, it's not really an issue, you just have a list of blocks in one part of the layout. Not terribly complicated. I have that for one site. Also, you may want to look at the views - are you using multiple views where you could be using one and using a filter to control the content based on the current page? It's hard to know how to help you without more details, such as what the views are showing...
